critters.name: White-Tailed Deer
critters.summary: Common woodland browser found throughout northern Michigan.
critters.fact: Deer can rotate their ears independently to pinpoint sounds.

critters.name: Raccoon
critters.summary: Highly adaptable nocturnal omnivore often seen near feeders.
critters.fact: Raccoons have extremely sensitive front paws that help identify food.

critters.name: Red Fox
critters.summary: Solitary predator known for intelligence and adaptability.
critters.fact: Foxes use Earthâ€™s magnetic field when hunting small prey.

critters.name: Coyote
critters.summary: Widespread adaptable canid common in rural Michigan.
critters.fact: Coyotes can run up to about 40 mph in short bursts.

critters.name: Blue Jay
critters.summary: Bold woodland songbird frequently visiting feeders.
critters.fact: Blue jays can mimic hawk calls to deter other birds.

critters.name: Northern Cardinal
critters.fact: Cardinals donâ€™t migrate and maintain territories all winter.

critters.name: Black-Capped Chickadee
critters.summary: Small energetic bird common at feeders.
critters.fact: Chickadees can lower body temperature at night to conserve energy.

critters.name: Mallard Duck
critters.fact: Mallards can sleep with one eye open for predator awareness.

critters.name: Canada Goose
critters.summary: Large migratory waterfowl often seen in flocks.
critters.fact: Geese fly in V formation to reduce wind resistance.

critters.name: Painted Turtle
critters.summary: Common basking turtle in ponds and wetlands.
critters.fact: Painted turtles can survive low oxygen conditions during winter.

critters.name: Spring Peeper
critters.summary: Tiny frog known for loud spring calls.
critters.fact: Their chorus is often one of the first signs of warming weather.

critters.name: Dragonfly
critters.summary: Fast flying insect common near water.
critters.fact: Dragonflies can fly in all directions including backward.

critters.name: Monarch Butterfly
critters.fact: Monarchs migrate thousands of miles between seasons.
